Understanding Correlated Random Effects Models

causal inference
Published

October 31, 2024

Background

In the world of panel data analysis, we often find ourselves choosing between fixed effects (FE) and random effects (RE) models. Each has its strengths and limitations. The FE model controls for all time-invariant unobserved heterogeneity but does not allow us to estimate the effects of those time-invariant covariates. On the other hand, the RE model allows for the inclusion of time-invariant variables but makes a strong assumption: that the unobserved individual-specific effects are uncorrelated with the regressors. What happens when that assumption doesn’t hold? That’s where the correlated random effects (CRE) model—or the hybrid model—steps in.

This article explores the motivation behind the CRE model, its mechanics, and its advantages over traditional FE and RE models. We also provide a hands-on example using R to illustrate how it works in practice.

Notation

Let us consider a standard panel data setup where we observe units \(i = 1, \dots, N\) over time periods \(t = 1, \dots, T\). The outcome is \(y_{it}\), and \(x_{it}\) is a vector of time-varying covariates. The generic random effects model is:

\[y_{it} = x_{it}'\beta + \alpha_i + \varepsilon_{it}\]

where \(\alpha_i\) is the individual-specific effect and \(\varepsilon_{it}\) is the idiosyncratic error term. The crucial RE assumption is:

\[\text{Cov}(x_{it}, \alpha_i) = 0\]

The CRE model relaxes this assumption by explicitly modeling the correlation between \(x_{it}\) and \(\alpha_i\).

A Closer Look

The CRE Model

The basic idea of the CRE model, popularized by Mundlak (1978) and further advocated by Schunck (2013), is to decompose the time-varying covariate \(x_{it}\) into two components:

\[x_{it} = \bar{x}_i + (x_{it} - \bar{x}_i)\]

where \(\bar{x}_i = \frac{1}{T} \sum_t x_{it}\) is the individual-specific mean of \(x_{it}\). The model then becomes:

\[y_{it} = (x_{it} - \bar{x}_i)'\beta_w + \bar{x}_i'\beta_b + \alpha_i + \varepsilon_{it}\]

Here, \(\beta_w\) captures the within-unit effect (similar to FE), and \(\beta_b\) captures the between-unit effect.

The beauty of this decomposition is that it lets us keep the random effects framework while controlling for possible correlation between \(x_{it}\) and \(\alpha_i\). The CRE model is estimated using RE methods but includes the person-level means \(\bar{x}_i\) as additional regressors.

When to Use CRE

The CRE model is useful when: - You suspect that \(x_{it}\) and \(\alpha_i\) are correlated. - You want to retain time-invariant covariates. - You want to decompose effects into within- and between-entity components.

It blends the strengths of both FE and RE while relaxing the unrealistic assumptions of pure RE models.

An Example

Let’s illustrate the differences among FE, RE, and CRE using R and a sample panel dataset.

  • R
library(plm)
library(dplyr)

# Simulate panel data
set.seed(42)
n <- 100
t <- 5
data <- data.frame(
  id = rep(1:n, each = t),
  time = rep(1:t, n)
)
data <- data %>%
  group_by(id) %>%
  mutate(
    x = rnorm(n(), mean = id/10),
    alpha = rnorm(1),
    eps = rnorm(n(), sd = 1),
    y = 1 + 0.5 * x + alpha + eps
  )

pdata <- pdata.frame(data, index = c("id", "time"))

# Fixed effects model
fe_model <- plm(y ~ x, data = pdata, model = "within")

# Random effects model
re_model <- plm(y ~ x, data = pdata, model = "random")

# Correlated Random Effects (Hybrid) model
pdata$mean_x <- ave(pdata$x, pdata$id, FUN = mean)
cre_model <- plm(y ~ x + mean_x, data = pdata, model = "random")

summary(fe_model)
summary(re_model)
summary(cre_model)

Bottom Line

  • The CRE model allows for correlation between covariates and unobserved effects by decomposing variables into within- and between-unit components.

  • It maintains the flexibility of random effects models while addressing potential bias due to endogeneity.

  • Unlike fixed effects, it allows for the estimation of time-invariant variables.

  • It is especially useful in policy evaluation and longitudinal data analysis when assumptions of standard RE models are not tenable.

Where to Learn More

A great place to start is the original paper by Schunck (2013), which provides a very accessible overview and comparison of different panel data methods. Mundlak’s (1978) foundational work is also worth reading. If you’re using Stata, the xtreg command with cre options can replicate much of this functionality. In R, you can use plm and manipulate the covariates manually as shown in the example above.

References

  • Schunck, R. (2013). Within and between estimates in random-effects models: Advantages and drawbacks of correlated random effects and hybrid models. The Stata Journal, 13(1), 65-76.

  • Mundlak, Y. (1978). On the pooling of time series and cross section data. Econometrica, 46(1), 69–85.
